Award.AwardTitle: Investigating the timing and consequences of Pleistocene megafaunal population collapse in the Neotropics
Award.AbstractNarration:
At the end of the last ice age, 15,000 years ago, the Americas had many species large mammals (Pleistocene megafauna) that were more diverse than those of the modern Serengeti. About that time, they quickly became extinct. There is much controversy about why animals such as big cats, elephants, horses, camels and ground sloths suddenly disappeared. Some scientists blame climate change, while others blame the arrival of human hunters. In the last few years, paleoecologists have developed a new way to investigate the population fluctuations of these extinct mammals: they count microscopic spores that were produced long ago, grew only on large amounts of dung, and are now preserved in lake sediments. The sudden disappearance of these spores in sediment cores is an excellent indicator of the disappearance of the Pleistocene megafauna. In this proposal, scientists will investigate the timing of the megafaunal population decline at sites in Panama, Brazil and Peru, and compare them with very detailed records of past climate change, and with the archaeological record. By doing so, scientists will be able to determine if climate change or the arrival of humans most likely caused the mass extinction.

The end of the last ice age was the most recent time when climates warmed almost as rapidly as under modern conditions, and there was huge instability in precipitation regimes. Investigating the potential link between extinction events and abrupt climate change has clear relevance to modern concerns. To observe which, if any, climate changes triggered population reductions or recoveries thousands of years ago, has repercussions for agricultural policy as well as conservation. Similarly, establishing whether the largest mammalian extinction event in the last 6 million years can be assigned to human actions is relevant to how we perceive our relationship to the natural world. Finally, the project will train students in paleoecology and produce materials for dissemination to large audiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project sought to identify the timing, causes and consequences of the extinction of Pleistocene megafuana (animals weighing >100 lbs) in South America. Fossil Sporormiella spores, a fungus of the enteric tract and dung of large herbivores, were used to identify the presence and approximate abundance of large herbivores. An analysis of modern sediments from nine lakes in SE Brazil confirmed that Sporormiella was only documented in lakes visited by large herbivores and that the abundance of Sporormiella was linked to the number of animals around the lake.

Samples recovered from ancient lake sediments provided a detailed history of the megafaunal decline at two locations in SE Brazil, and eight Andean lakes. Fossil charcoal and pollen were analyzed for all lakes and high-resolution sediment chemistry was analyzed for some settings. We found that the decline in megafaunal abundance was quantifiable at all locations, and occurred by 12,800 years ago at evey site.In sites with continuous sedimentary records spanning the last 25,000 years the decline appeared to occur in multiple stages, with the first big population collapse occurring between 21,000 and 19,000 years ago. A later collapse occurred between 15,800 and 14,000 years ago with functional extinction occurring by 12,800 years ago. The first collapse of megafauna appears to coincide with warmer and wetter conditions and is thought to be a population response to adverse climatic conditions. At presetn we cannot say if this decline was an extinction of some species within the fauna or a general lowering of all populations.

The megafaunal declines post 15,800 years ago were always accompanied by an increase in charcoal abundance, indicating the appearance of fire in the landscape. Fire in these settings is deemed very unlikely without humans providing the source of ignition. The loss of megafuana at 12,800 was again commonly linked to a further step up in fire frequency. We infer that these declines indicate the invovlvement of humans as hunters and/or landscape manipulators in the final extinction of the megafauna. 

The effect of the loss of megafauna cannot be isolated from the impact of fire and rapid climate change in this landscape. In some settings the megafuanal decline coincided with floras without modern analog, but in other setting there was no such relationship.

The suggestion that humans were using fire in the Andes as early as 15,800 years ago in the Andes pushes back the earliest human occupation of the Andes by 3000 years compared with the earliest known archaeological evidence. These are provocative results and should encourage further investigation of the early human history in the Andes. From an ecological viewpoint, the occurrence of fire in the late Pleistocene altered landscape at every site we surveyed. If, as we suspect, those fires were attributable to human agency, the role of humans shaping Andean landscapes did not begin within the mid-Holocene as is generally reported, but spans the entirety of the Holocene.
